Examples:

import times
import timezones

# Create a timezone representing a static offset from UTC.
let zone = tz"+02:30"
echo initDateTime(1, mJan, 2000, 12, 00, 00, zone)
# => 2000-01-01T12:00:00+02:30

# Static offset timezones can also be created with the proc ``staticTz``,
# which is preferable if the offset is only known at runtime.
doAsert zone == staticTz(hours = -2, minutes = -30)

# Create a timezone representing a timezone in the IANA timezone database.
let stockholm = tz"Europe/Stockholm"
echo initDateTime(1, mJan, 1850, 00, 00, 00, stockholm)
# => 1850-01-01T00:00:00+01:12

# Get a list of timezones used by a country.
# The country is specified with it's two character country code,
# see ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.
let sweden = tzNames("SE")
echo sweden
# => @["Europe/Stockholm"]

# Note that some countries use many different timezones.
let usa = tzNames("US")
echo usa
# => @[
#   "America/New_York",  "America/Adak",      "America/Phoenix",     "America/Yakutat",
#   "Pacific/Honolulu",  "America/Nome",      "America/Los_Angeles", "America/Detroit",
#   "America/Chicago",   "America/Boise",     "America/Juneau",      "America/Metlakatla",
#   "America/Anchorage", "America/Menominee", "America/Sitka",       "America/Denver"
# ]

# Get a list of countries that are known to use a timezone.
# Note that some timezones are used by multiple countries.
let bangkok = tz"Asia/Bangkok"
echo bangkok.countries
# => @["TH", "KH", "LA", "VN"]

Imports

timezonefile, sharedtypes, tzversion

Types

Country = string

A country is represented by a two character country code, using ISO 3166-1 alpha-2.

See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-2.

TzData = TzDataImpl
Contains the timezone data for a specific IANA timezone database version. 
Dms = object
  deg*, min*, sec*: int16
A coordinate specified in degrees (deg), minutes (min) and seconds (sec). 
Coordinates = object
  lat*, lon*: Dms
Earth coordinates.

Lets

EmbeededTzData = embeededTzDataImpl
The embeeded tzdata. Not available if -d:timezonesNoEmbeed is used.

Procs

proc version(db: TzData): string {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
The version of the IANA timezone database being represented by db. The string consist of the year plus a letter. For example, "2018a" is the first database release of 2018, "2018b" the second one and so on. 
proc countries(db: TzData; tzName: string): seq[Country] {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Get a list of countries that are known to use tzName. The result might be empty. Note that some countries use multiple timezones. 
proc countries(db: TzData; tz: Timezone): seq[Country] {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Shorthand for db.countries(tz.name) 
proc tzNames(db: TzData; country: Country): seq[string] {...}{.raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}

Get a list of timezone names for timezones known to be used by country.

Raises a ValueError if country isn't exactly two characters.

proc location(db: TzData; tzName: string): Option[Coordinates] {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}

Get the coordinates of a timezone. This is generally the coordinates of the city in the timezone name. E.g db.location"Europe/Stockholm" will give the the coordinates of Stockholm, the capital of Sweden.

Will return none(Coordinates) if the timezone either doesn't exist in the database, or if it doesn't have any coordinates in the database.

proc location(db: TzData; tz: Timezone): Option[Coordinates] {...}{.inline, raises: [],
    tags: [].}
Shorthand for db.location(tz.name) 
proc tz(db: TzData; tzName: string): Timezone {...}{.inline, raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Create a timezone from a timezone name, where the timezone name is one of the following:
  • The string "LOCAL", representing the systems local timezone.
  • A string of the form "HH:MM:SS" or "HH:MM", representing a fixed offset from UTC. Note that the sign will be the opposite when compared to staticTz. For example, tz"+01:00" is the same as staticTz(hour = -1).
  • A timezone name from the IANA timezone database, also listed on wikipedia.

In case tzName does not follow any of these formats, or the timezone name doesn't exist in the database, a ValueError exception is raised.

proc parseJsonTimezones(content: string): TzData {...}{.
    raises: [KeyError, ValueError, JsonKindError, Exception, JsonParsingError],
    tags: [ReadIOEffect].}
Parse a timezone database from its JSON representation. 
proc parseJsonTimezones(s: Stream): TzData {...}{.
    raises: [KeyError, ValueError, JsonKindError, Exception, JsonParsingError],
    tags: [ReadIOEffect].}
Parse a timezone database from its JSON representation. 
proc loadJsonTimezones(path: string): TzData {...}{.raises: [IOError, Exception, KeyError,
    ValueError, JsonKindError, JsonParsingError], tags: [ReadIOEffect].}
Load a timezone database from a JSON file. 
proc countries(tzName: string): seq[Country] {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Convenience proc using the embeeded timezone database.

Examples:

doAssert countries"Europe/Stockholm" == @["SE"]
doAssert countries"Asia/Bangkok" == @["TH", "KH", "LA", "VN"]
proc countries(tz: Timezone): seq[Country] {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Convenience proc using the embeeded timezone database. 
proc tzNames(country: Country): seq[string] {...}{.raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Convenience proc using the embeeded timezone database.

Examples:

doAssert "SE".tzNames == @["Europe/Stockholm"]
doAssert "VN".tzNames == @["Asia/Ho_Chi_Minh", "Asia/Bangkok"]
proc location(tzName: string): Option[Coordinates] {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Convenience proc using the embeeded timezone database.

Examples:

import
  times, options

doAssert $(location"Europe/Stockholm") ==
    r"Some(59 20 0 N 18 3 0 E)"
doAssert (location"Etc/UTC").isNone
doAssert utc().location.isNone
proc location(tz: Timezone): Option[Coordinates] {...}{.inline, raises: [], tags: [].}
Convenience proc using the embeeded timezone database 
proc tz(tzName: string): Timezone {...}{.raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Convenience proc using the embeeded timezone database.

Examples:

import
  times

let stockholm = tz"Europe/Stockholm"
let dt = initDateTime(1, mJan, 1850, 0, 0, 0, stockholm)
doAssert $dt == "1850-01-01T00:00:00+01:12"
proc staticTz(hours, minutes, seconds: int = 0): Timezone {...}{.noSideEffect, raises: [],
    tags: [].}
Create a timezone using a static offset from UTC.

Examples:

import
  times

let tz = staticTz(hours = -2, minutes = -30)
doAssert $tz == "+02:30"
let dt = initDateTime(1, mJan, 2000, 12, 0, 0, tz)
doAssert $dt == "2000-01-01T12:00:00+02:30"
proc initCoordinates(lat, lon: (int16, int16, int16)): Coordinates {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
proc `$`(coords: Coordinates): string {...}{.raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}

Examples:

let loc = initCoordinates((1'i16, 2'i16, 3'i16), (4'i16, 5'i16, 6'i16))
doAssert $loc == r"1 2 3 N 4 5 6 E"
